hook.text: A cracked tea bowl is more beautiful than a perfect one. That's wabi-sabi.

buildup.text: Wabi-sabi is the Japanese aesthetic of finding beauty in imperfection and impermanence.

discovery.text: It's rooted in Zen Buddhism: nothing lasts, nothing is finished, nothing is perfect.

twist.text: The Japanese art of kintsugi repairs broken pottery with gold â€” making the cracks part of the beauty.

climax.text: In a culture obsessed with perfection, wabi-sabi offers radical relief: flaws are features.

punchline.text: Perfection is boring. Cracks tell stories.
